unnormalised: New Delhi: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has issued a directive mandating the digitization of healthcare records nationwide, requiring integration with the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (ABDM). This initiative aims to streamline patient data management and enhance accessibility for healthcare providers across the country.
normalised: New Delhi: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has issued a directive mandating the digitization of healthcare records nationwide, requiring integration with the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (A-B-D-M). This initiative aims to streamline patient data management and enhance accessibility for healthcare providers across the country.

unnormalised: Under this mandate, all hospitals and clinics, both public and private, are required to assign a unique Health ID (also known as an ABHA number) to each patient. This ABHA number, a 14-digit identifier, will serve as a single point of reference for all health-related information, including medical history, diagnoses, treatments, and test results. The ABHA number for Mr. R.K.Gupta for instance is recorded as 4567-8901-2345-6789 in the central database.
normalised: Under this mandate, all hospitals and clinics, both public and private, are required to assign a unique Health I-D (also known as an A-B-H-A number) to each patient. This A-B-H-A number, a fourteen-digit identifier, will serve as a single point of reference for all health-related information, including medical history, diagnoses, treatments, and test results. The A-B-H-A number for Mr. R.K. Gupta for instance is recorded as four thousand five hundred and sixty seven dash eight thousand nine hundred and one dash two thousand three hundred and forty five dash six thousand seven hundred and eighty nine in the central database.

unnormalised: The implementation will be phased, with larger hospitals having to comply by 31/12/2024, and smaller clinics and healthcare centers given until 30/06/2025. The Unique Health ID initiative mandates that all participating healthcare providers must adhere to strict data privacy and security protocols to protect patient information. There have been some privacy concerns raised regarding the sharing of personal information under the ABHA ID policy, specifically its impact on data protection and security for the general public.
normalised: The implementation will be phased, with larger hospitals having to comply by thirty first December two thousand and twenty four, and smaller clinics and healthcare centers given until thirtieth June two thousand and twenty five. The Unique Health I-D initiative mandates that all participating healthcare providers must adhere to strict data privacy and security protocols to protect patient information. There have been some privacy concerns raised regarding the sharing of personal information under the A-B-H-A I-D policy, specifically its impact on data protection and security for the general public.

unnormalised: The Health Ministry has reassured citizens that robust measures are in place to prevent unauthorized access and misuse of data. Each patient also gets a PHR (Personal Health Records) address. This address, formatted as username@abdm, allows individuals to consolidate and manage their health records from various sources in a secure, digital environment. For example, Ms. Aisha Khan's PHR address is aisha.khan@abdm.
normalised: The Health Ministry has reassured citizens that robust measures are in place to prevent unauthorized access and misuse of data. Each patient also gets a P-H-R (Personal Health Records) address. This address, formatted as username at A-B-D-M, allows individuals to consolidate and manage their health records from various sources in a secure, digital environment. For example, Ms. Aisha Khan's P-H-R address is aisha dot khan at A-B-D-M.

unnormalised: "The ABDM is a game-changer for healthcare in India," said Dr. Vinod Paul, Member (Health), NITI Aayog. "By assigning unique Health IDs and integrating digital records, we are empowering patients with greater control over their health information and enabling healthcare providers to deliver more efficient and personalized care."
normalised: "The A-B-D-M is a game-changer for healthcare in India," said Doctor Vinod Paul, Member (Health), N-I-T-I Aayog. "By assigning unique Health I-Ds and integrating digital records, we are empowering patients with greater control over their health information and enabling healthcare providers to deliver more efficient and personalized care."

unnormalised: Healthcare providers must also register themselves on the Healthcare Professionals Registry (HPR), which assigns them a unique identifier. This identifier, formatted as a numerical code, helps establish their credentials and facilitates interoperability across different healthcare systems. Dr. Priya Sharma, for instance, has the identifier HPR1234567890.
normalised: Healthcare providers must also register themselves on the Healthcare Professionals Registry (H-P-R), which assigns them a unique identifier. This identifier, formatted as a numerical code, helps establish their credentials and facilitates interoperability across different healthcare systems. Doctor Priya Sharma, for instance, has the identifier H-P-R one two three four five six seven eight nine zero.

unnormalised: The initiative will also facilitate the seamless exchange of health information between healthcare providers through the use of standardized codes, such as ICD-10 for diagnoses and SNOMED CT for clinical terms. This interoperability will improve the accuracy and efficiency of healthcare delivery, reducing the risk of errors and ensuring that patients receive the right care at the right time. The initiative further aims to reduce fraud and mismanagement of resources that plague public welfare programs.
